thread.title: Disabled woman rescued after tornado moves mobile home
thread.title_full: Disabled woman rescued after tornado moves mobile home - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: cbs8
title: Disabled woman rescued after tornado moves mobile home
text:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) - The latest about storms in Louisiana and Mississippi (all times local).
5:50 p.m.
Police in a New Orleans suburb say rain and speed contributed to a fatal wreck as the remnants of Hurricane Patricia swept across Louisiana and south Mississippi.
Kenner police Lt. Brian McGregor says 24-year-old Raja Sikandar Mahmood's Nissan 350Z went into a canal.
Earlier Sunday, a disabled elderly woman was rescued after a small tornado knocked her trailer home in St. Rose off its moorings. St. Charles Parish emergency preparedness director Ron Perry says she appeared to have discomfort but did not appear to be injured.
The National Weather Service says it was an EF-0 Perry tornado.
Meteorologist Danielle Manning says some areas had more than 6 inches of rain by midafternoon Sunday, and more was expected Monday. Up to 7 inches was expected in south Mississippi through Monday.
1:22 p.m.
The St. Charles Parish emergency preparedness director says a disabled elderly woman had to be rescued after a tornado knocked her trailer home in St. Rose off its moorings. Ron Perry says she appeared to have discomfort but did not appear to be injured.
Perry says the small tornado hit as the remnants of Hurricane Patricia swept across Louisiana and south Mississippi.
National Weather Service meteorologist Danielle Manning says some areas southwest of Lake Pontchartrain had more than 6 inches of rain by midafternoon Sunday, and were expected to get more through Monday. Parts of coastal Mississippi had up to 5 inches, up to 7 expected through Monday.
Meteorologist Donald Jones says southwest Louisiana got 3 to 4 inches, with a total of 4 to 5 expected by Monday night.
